page.title: 09FARMING AROUND EPPING
page.content: In 1936 one man with two horses could plough only one acre in a day. In 1985 one man with a 100 h.p. tractor can plough 25 acres in a day. This is one way in which farming has changed. {Epping Bury Farm}employed 22 men in 1932: now the 183 hectares are farmed by the owner plus 3 men. Growing cereals alone has not been {economical}in recent years, and a variety of crops is now planted. The crops grown today are wheat, peas, oats, oilseed rape, barley, and beans. Oilseed rape is a very widely-grown crop locally. This year the farmer has 118 fat cattle which are kept for beef. Today's farmworker works from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.and gets{Â£110}per week. In the past milk was delivered by horse and cart: now, in 1985 milk is delivered by tankers. (cont.)
